summary: This document is a series of emails from Christopher J. Dilorio, a self-proclaimed whistleblower, sent between November 2020 and December 2020. The emails are addressed to various recipients, including judges, FBI agents, and SEC officials, and detail Dilorio's allegations of widespread corruption, obstruction, and criminal activity within the SEC, FINRA, and related financial institutions. He claims his whistleblower information, submitted via TCRs (Tip, Complaint, or Referral), exposes massive frauds involving money laundering, naked short selling, and the protection of entities like Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE).

events.title: Dilorio files Knight Capital TCR
events.description: Christopher Dilorio files his initial TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) with SEC official Sean Berger, alleging corruption and fraud at Knight Capital.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital suffers a massive trading 'glitch' causing huge losses; Dilorio claims this proved Knight was insolvent and was covered up.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial acquires KCG Holdings in a $1.4 billion all-cash merger; Dilorio alleges it was fraudulent, with KCG insolvent and fraud assets written down just prior.

events.title: NASDAQ Acquires Verafin
events.description: NASDAQ announces a $2.8 billion acquisition of Verafin, a financial crimes detection firm; Dilorio implies this acknowledges a massive money laundering problem.

events.title: Dilorio's Final Allegations
events.description: Dilorio claims NITE/Virtu is insolvent as of this date due to ongoing abusive naked shorting and money laundering, facilitated by SEC obstruction.

events.title: Email Correspondence Sent
events.description: Dilorio sends a series of emails summarizing his allegations and appealing the preliminary denial of his whistleblower award.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio alleges a massive, ongoing fraud involving Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE) centered on abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.
He claims the SEC, including Chairman Jay Clayton and officials like Jane Norberg, has engaged in criminal obstruction to protect NITE and other entities while denying his whistleblower awards.
Dilorio asserts a corrupt relationship exists between the SEC and Jefferies CEO Richard Handler, benefiting from frauds and influencing cases like that of Dan Kamensky.
He references specific financial entities and shells like Net Element (NETE), AppTech, Blink Charging, and Brown Brothers Harriman as part of the fraud ecosystem.
The emails suggest Dilorio's information has been used by the SEC/FINRA to bring some actions (e.g., against Sason, BBH) while deliberately omitting key players like NITE from complaints.
